metadata.title: Mass transport and catalytic activity in hierarchical/non-hierarchical and internal/external nanostructures: A novel comparison using 3D simulation

Fig. 1 Schematic representations of the nanostructures considered in simulations: (a) non-hierarchical external, (b) non-hierarchical internal, (c) hierarchical external and (d) hierarchical internal nanostructures. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Cross-section of simulation geometries with the geometrical parameters of reaction surface: (a) non-hierarchical external, (b) non-hierarchical internal, (c) hierarchical external and (d) hierarchical internal nanostructures; the solid-phase in gray color and the void-phase in white color. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Specific activity and fuel average concentration at the electrode surface during the oxidation of 0.5M reducing agent at 1V overpotential for a wide range of diffusion coefficients at k 0 =0.0325cm/s on corresponding nanostructures. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Mass activity of the oxidation of 0.5M reducing agent at 1V overpotential on corresponding nanostructures for a wide range of diffusion coefficients at k 0 =0.0325cm/s. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Thiele modulus for oxidation reaction of 0.5M reducing agent on corresponding nanostructures for a wide range of diffusion coefficients at k 0 =0.0325cm/s. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effectiveness factor of oxidation reaction of 0.5M reducing agent on corresponding nanostructures for a wide range of diffusion coefficients at (a) k 0 =0.0324cm/s, (b) k 0 =0.324cm/s and (c) with respect to k 0/D. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 pH-shift in the vicinity of corresponding nanostructures electrode during an oxidation of 0.5M reducing agent at 1V overpotential for a wide range of diffusion coefficients at k 0 =0.0325cm/s. Fig. 7 Mass transport and catalytic activity in hierarchical/non-hierarchical and internal/external nanostructures: A novel comparison using 3D simulation Mohammad Al-Halhouli a ⁎ Jochen Kieninger b Olena Yurchenko a ⁎ Gerald Urban a b a Freiburg Materials Research Center (FMF), University of Freiburg, 79104 Freiburg, Germany Freiburg Materials Research Center (FMF) University of Freiburg Freiburg 79104 Germany b Department of Microsystems Engineering (IMTEK), University of Freiburg, 79110 Freiburg, Germany Department of Microsystems Engineering (IMTEK) University of Freiburg Freiburg 79110 Germany ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Freiburg Materials Research Center (FMF), University of Freiburg, Stefan-Meier-str. 21, 79104 Freiburg, Germany. Freiburg Materials Research Center (FMF) University of Freiburg Freiburg 79104 Germany Graphical abstract The effect of the geometrical configuration of nanostructured catalyst on mass transport and catalytic activity is investigated based on 3D simulations of hierarchical external (H-Ex), hierarchical internal (H-In), non-hierarchical external (N-Ex) and non-hierarchical internal (N-In) nanostructures in a wide range of diffusion coefficients. The hierarchical external nanostructures have proven to be the most effective catalysis of an active species, especially with low diffusion coefficient, due to their high specific activity and high utilization of catalytic surface. The distinct organization of nanostructured materials influences several catalytic characteristics, like selectivity, sensitivity or catalytic efficiency. This paper studies the effect of geometrical configuration of nanostructured catalyst on mass transport and catalytic activity based on 3D simulations of hierarchical external, hierarchical internal, non-hierarchical external and non-hierarchical internal nanostructures. Generally, external nanostructures revealed higher utilization of catalytic surface than the internal nanostructures. Among the four investigated nanostructures, the mass transport in hierarchical external nanostructures was found to be the best; they even showed kinetic controlled regime for the species with low diffusion coefficient. In contrast, hierarchical internal nanostructures showed slightly less specific activity than non-hierarchical internal nanostructures because of higher total diffusional resistance and longer diffusional path. As a result, although hierarchical nanostructures possess large surface area, only the hierarchical external nanostructures provided an outstanding accessibility of active sites. The obtained results provide the tool for understanding the catalytic efficiency in complex nanostructure and phenomena that are technically difficult to measure. Keywords Hierarchical nanostructures 3D-simulation Catalytic activity Mass transport Thiele modulus 1 Introduction Applications of nanoporous electrodes in electrochemical devices, like fuel cells [1,2], supercapacitors [3], batteries [4], glucose sensors [5], etc., have become a significant growing field during last decades. In the field of catalytic reactions, nanoporous electrodes have gained the significance because of their high surface-to-volume ratio, which results in high catalytic surface area [6,7]. The total catalytic surface area can be influenced by roughness factor (Rf), which is defined as the ratio between the total nanoscopic catalytic surface area and the geometrical surface area [8]. There are a large number of nanostructures that have been reported for several catalytic reactions. Therefore, tuning the nanostructures to a specific catalytic reaction and optimizing the catalytic activity are of great importance, because the identification of an optimal nanostructure is still a great challenge [9]. Catalytic activity is proportional to reaction rate, which is defined by the number of molecules that get catalyzed per second. Thus, catalytic activity depends on the number of active sites and on the average rate of molecules turnover at active sites [10–12]. Besides the chemical characteristics, morphology of nanostructures plays a key role in the catalytic performance because of its influence on the accessibility of the active sites [13]. The pore-size is thereby a key factor for the determination of pore accessibility due to its impact on diffusion resistance. Based on pore-size, the porous material is described as either microporous (<2nm), mesoporous (2–50nm), or macroporous (>50nm) [14,15]. Recently, many synthesis processes associated with protocols for pore morphology adjustment were reported, for example, alloying/dealloying process [16,17], annealing process [18,19], templating method [20], pulsed electrodeposition [21], and cyclic electrodeposition [22]. The nanostructures can be classified based on their morphology into non-hierarchical nanostructures, also called 1D nanostructures, like nanowires [23], nanorods [24], and nanotubes [25], or hierarchical nanostructures, also called 3D nanostructures, such as flower-like [26], spherical nanostructures [27], nanopropeller-shaped [28], nanorings [29], and nanohelices [30]. Non-hierarchical nanostructures are composed of one level or one direction of the catalytic surface area, whereas hierarchical nanostructures are composed of macro- and micro-/mesostructures, which are assembled in more than one dimension [24,31]. In 1998, Yang et al. reported the first hierarchical porous nanostructures. These nanostructures were adjustable from 10nm to several micrometers [32]. Currently, there are several synthesis procedures for hierarchical nanostructures; they can be synthesized either by non-template methods by self-assembly of crystallites [31] or by template method [20,31] using hard/soft templates or bio-molecules foams. The diffusion of reactants inside porous nanostructures is influenced by the geometry of pores. In non-hierarchical nanostructures, the reactant molecules suffer from the high mass transfer resistance inside the pores, and in consequence the molecules were restrained from reaching some active sites [9]. Pore accessibility can be increased by using 3D interconnected pores because of the enhancement of the diffusion of fuel molecules [31]. Therefore, hierarchical nanostructures, which can enhance the accessibility of active sites, are considered as candidates for optimizing the mass-transport limitations in non-hierarchical nanostructures and for enhancing the catalytic activity for the desired reaction [9,31,33]. Thus, hierarchical nanostructures are the best candidates for catalytic applications with slow kinetics [34]. Additionally, the hierarchical nanostructures are well-employed in nature, lungs and kidneys are examples of improving the diffusion of slow diffusive nutrients and oxygen in a network of vessels [35]. However, hierarchical nanostructures are expensive due to the high metal usage [36]. Modelling of mass transport and catalytic efficiency of porous layers, including hierarchical nanostructures, was carried out by several groups [37–41]. Many groups optimized the catalytic activity of porous layers by introducing a distributor channel (macropore) that interconnects the meso-/micropores, i.e., porous layer of hierarchical nanostructures [42–46]. The significant macropore characteristics are the distributor geometry [43], volume fraction [43–46], pore-size [44,45], and the optimal link between macropores and meso-/micropores [43,47–49]. For example, Coppens and coworkers found that, in gases, the diffusion in macropores is the only limitation of the pores kinetics [46], but small pores are also significant in gas conversion simply because of the multitude of small pores [35]. In this paper, we investigate four configurations of porous layer, hierarchical and non-hierarchical of external and internal nanostructures, by means of 3D simulation in order to study the effect of the morphology on catalytic activity. These geometries are based on experimental investigations of external nanostructures [23]. The 3D simulation was used to overcome the symmetry limitations of hierarchical nanostructures, and to provide a general and more realistic model that estimates catalytic activity of any nanostructures geometry. We considered, as illustrated in Fig. 1 , vertical grown cylindrical nanowires for non-hierarchical external nanostructures (N-Ex) (Fig. 1a) and a sea-urchin nanostructure for hierarchical external nanostructures (H-Ex) (Fig. 1c). For investigation of internal nanostructures, we chose two previously reported geometries that are analogous to the imprint of our external nanostructures, especially in relation to the equivalent geometrical parameters, like Rf and surface area, for the purpose of comparison. The nanostructures with vertical cylindrical holes [47,50] was considered for non-hierarchical internal nanostructures (N-In) (Fig. 1b) and the imprint of a sea-urchin nanostructures that contains macropores as distributor channels to micro-/mesostructures [42,46,51] was considered for hierarchical internal nanostructures (H-In) (Fig. 1d). Unlike the investigations reported in literature, the main goal of this paper is the investigation and comparison of the reaction kinetics on several proposed nanostructures based on their morphology because of the expected dissimilar mechanisms of mass transport inside these geometries. In this paper, a model system that combines the electrocatalytic and mass transport behaviors is applied. Thus, it provides fundamental understanding of the catalytic activity based on molecules diffusion and kinetic parameters. Furthermore, the study was extended to the investigations of diffusional resistance inside each porous structure through Thiele modulus and the effectiveness factor. Further evaluations of the migration of protons resulting from the oxidation process were carried out by consideration of pH-value at the direct vicinity of the porous electrode [23]. Nevertheless, some factors that influence kinetic parameters, like adsorption and temperature [52–54] as well as the electrolyte conductivity and the associated influence of potential on ions migration were not considered within the scope of this paper. 2 Methods 2.1 Reaction kinetics The reaction kinetics at the anode was investigated in our simulations by considering an arbitrary organic fuel as a reducing agent (Red). Eq. (1) represents the oxidation process occurring at the anode [55]: (1) Red→Ox+e The kinetics of the reactions occurring on the electrode surface is influenced by the electrode potential [56,57]. The current-potential characteristics were determined according to Butler–Volmer equation which predicts the currents resulting from the overpotential on the electrode [57]: (2) j = j 0 C [ C O x exp ( − α F η R T ) − C R e d exp ( ( 1 − α ) F η R T ) ] with (3) j 0 = F k 0 C O x 1 − α C R e d α = F k 0 C where j is the current density (A/m2), F is the Faraday constant (C/mol), j 0 is exchange current density (A/m2), C is reference concentration at which the bulk concentrations of oxidizing and reducing agents are equal (mol/m3), C i is the concentration at the electrode surface of species i (mol/m3), i is either Ox or Red, α is the charge transfer coefficient, k 0 is the standard heterogeneous rate constant (m/s), ɳ is the overpotential (V), R is the gas constant (J/(molK)) and T absolute temperature (K) [56]. 2.2 Mass transport The mass transport of corresponding species, i.e., reducing agent (fuel) or oxidizing agent (protons), was only derived by diffusion and no convection mass transport was exerted at any of simulation boundary conditions in this paper. Therefore, isotropic diffusive mass transport was modeled according to the Fick’s equation which is a built-in equation of COMSOL [58]: (4) N i = − D i ∇ c i + u c i where N i represents the flux per unit area, i.e., the number of moles of substances i per unit of time per unit of area (mol/(m2 s)), D i is the diffusion coefficient, u is the field velocity, and c i is the concentration of i (mol/m3) [59]. Since there was no convection transfer, the velocity field u =0m/s. Therefore, Eq. (4) were simplified to: (5) N i = − D i ∇ c i 2.3 Thiele modulus To study the impact of nanostructures morphology on the catalytic efficiency of the electrode based on the diffusion of fuel molecules, the reaction rate was maintained constant in all simulations. The simplest model to analyze the catalytic activity and the diffusional resistance of dispersed species in a porous electrode is the effectiveness factor ɳ based on Thiele modulus ϕ n [60]. Thiele modulus is a dimensionless number composed of the surface reaction rate, i.e. kinetic activity, divided by the diffusion rate through the catalyst pore [61]. Based on the theory of Thiele modulus, the better diffusion profile has lower Thiele modulus. For each nanostructure, Thiele modulus was derived (see Supplementary information) based on the following equation [62,63]: (6) ϕ n = L P ⋅ k D where (7) k = k 0 A r V D where LP is the diffusion distance (m), D is the diffusion coefficient (m2/s), VD is the volume available for diffusion of molecules (m3), and Ar is the reaction surface area (m2). The effectiveness factor is the ratio of the observed reaction rate to the assumed rate without diffusional limitations [63]. Likewise, the effectiveness factor is defined in the following equation: (8) η = tan h ( ϕ n ) ϕ n 2.4 Henderson-Hasselbalch equation The buffer is usually used as an electrolyte in fuel cells or sensors analyte for avoiding the sudden drop of pH-value in consequence of protons that are produced by the oxidation process of organic fuels at the solid phase [52]. Thus, the buffer conditions were applied inside the fuel cell in order of pH-value investigation, since the electrode kinetics is dependent on the pH-value [52]. Therefore, Henderson-Hasselbalch equation (Eq. (9)) was used for modelling pH-value within the simulation vessel[64]: (9) pH = p K a + log ( [ A − ] [ H A ] ) where HA is a weak acid, A− is its conjugate base and K a is the acid dissociation constant which represents the pH-value of the electrolyte when the concentrations of the weak acid and its conjugate base are equal [64]. 2.5 Simulation software Finite element simulator COMSOL Multiphysics® version 4.4 was used for investigating and comparing the catalytic activity of the four proposed nanostructures. The catalytic activity was examined in a wide range of diffusion coefficients. 2.6 Geometry of nanostructures Cross-sections of the geometries of the investigated nanostructures are shown in Fig. 2 . For each nanostructure, the length of the internal or external nanostructures (L), the width of solid-phase (S) and the width of the void-phase (V) were set to 200nm, 5nm, and 5nm, respectively. Accordingly, L, S, V parameters were invariable in this paper because the objective of this study was the comparison of catalytic efficiency of different nanostructures rather than the optimization of these nanostructures. The macrostructure in the hierarchical nanostructures was simulated by a void-phase hemisphere and solid-phase hemisphere for internal and external nanostructures, respectively. The microstructures were simulated by void-phase cylinder and solid-phase cylinder for the internal and external nanostructures, respectively. In Fig. 2, the gray color represents the solid-phase and the white color refers to the void-phase. The reaction surface, at which the oxidation of reducing agent takes place, is the surface of the solid phase. Additionally, all nanostructures were designed to have the same total area of reaction surface, i.e., the area of macrostructures in hierarchical nanostructures equals the area of the base (flat surface) of the non-hierarchical nanostructures and the area of microstructures were always equal among all nanostructures. Each nanostructure had a stand-alone 3D component in one simulation file. In each component, one nanostructure was placed at the bottom of a cylindrical simulation vessel of length 5μm. Moreover, the top of the cylinder has been set as an inflow boundary condition at which the concentrations of fuel and phosphate buffered saline (PBS) were assigned. 2.7 Medium and reaction surface In simulations, it was considered that the oxidation process of a hypothetical fuel releases only one proton. The overpotential was set to 1V in all simulations. Since the kinetics parameters k 0 , j0 , C and α must be relevant to each other because they are used separately in independent simulations, the kinetics parameters of methanol were applied as a first order reaction for simplification purpose of the simulation. The kinetics parameters k 0, j0 , C and α in all simulations had the values of 0.0325cm/s, 2.8 pA/cm2, 0.1M and 0.4, respectively [65]. The simulations were performed considering PBS at pH 7.4 consisting of 85.2mM HPO4 2− and 14.8mM H2PO4 −. All redox reactions took place at the reaction surface (Fig. 2) according to Faraday’s law[57]: (10) j = ∓ n F N 0 , i Where the reaction rate (N 0,i) represents the flux per unit area at reaction surface; negative sign indicates consumption of reducing agent and positive sign indicates the production of oxidizing agent. The reducing agent concentration was 500mM at the inflow boundary of the simulation vessel. Consequently, the reducing agent diffuses from the inflow boundary towards the reaction surface, where the reducing agent gets oxidized according to Eq. (10). 2.8 Solver and investigation parameters The default COMSOL Multiphysics® 4.4 stationary solver was used for implementing a separate study for each single nanostructure (Supplementary information). For application of stationary solver, the assumption was that the concentration at the inflow boundary and the oxidation rate at the reaction surface do not vary in time. Diffusion coefficient was the sweep parameter in all simulations. Each study was extended to seven diffusion coefficients, D =10−7, 10−6, 10−5, 10−4, 10−3, 10−2 and 10−1 cm2/s, by an auxiliary sweep. The wide range of notional diffusion coefficients was used in the simulation to investigate the mass transport inside the porous layer and to understand the significance of pore accessibility. Multifunctional massively parallel spares (MUMPS) direct solver with the default settings was the type of the stationary solver. A Windows 7Home Premium (64-bit) with a 1.90GHz AMD A4–3305M APU with Radeon(tm) HD Graphics and 4 GB RAM was used for performing all the simulations in this paper. The average solver run time is two hours for each nanostructure. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Specific and mass activity The influence of the geometry of a porous layer on the specific activity and mass activity were investigated by simulation. Specific activity is defined as the current per unit of electrochemical active surface area (A/cm2) [66], whereas mass activity is reported as the normalized current density per unit of catalyst mass (A/g) [67]. In the following, specific activity as well as mass activity were calculated according to the void phase and solid phase in the geometries that are shown in Fig. 2. As described in the simulation methods, we applied the Butler-Volmer equation to simulate the electrochemical kinetics and the current that was generated on each nanostructure based on the electrode potential. As shown in Fig. 3 , the specific activity of external nanostructures was higher than that of internal nanostructures for species with low diffusion coefficient. However, there was no significant difference in specific activity between H-In and N-In. The equivalent specific activity observed in the internal nanostructures was properly due to the small macropore-size. There are many publications that investigate increasing the efficiency of internal nanostructures by adjusting macropore-/mesopore-size and pore connectivity [37–49,51]. In the present paper, we distinguish between several morphologies of nanostructures and highlight the influence of the pore direction (internal or external) on pore accessibility, and therefore on specific and mass activity. Nevertheless, as shown in Fig. 3, the specific activity of N-Ex and H-Ex at D =10−10 m2/s are 75% and 244% higher than specific activity of internal nanostructures, respectively. However, at D =10−9 m2/s, the specific activities of N-Ex and H-Ex become 26% and 41% higher than that of internal nanostructures. And when the diffusion coefficient was higher than D =10−7 m2/s, the specific activities of all nanostructures became equal for set parameters. The simulations of the four nanostructures contain fixed parameters for Butler–Volmer equation, fixed concentrations at the inflow boundary, and equal catalytic active surface area. Consequently, the mass transport is the only factor that distinguishes between the four nanostructures through their unequal diffusional limitations. Thus, specific activities for all nanostructures become equal when they reach the maximum possible value, which occurs when the molecules of reducing agent reached the complete catalytic active surface area with the same concentration. The maximum specific activity for investigated nanostructures occurs when D is larger than 10−7 m2/s according to the given kinetic parameters (Fig. 3). Nonetheless, H-Ex reaches 92% and 99% of the maximum possible specific activity at D =10−10 m2/s and 10−9 m2/s (Fig. 3), respectively. Simultaneously, the specific activity of N-Ex reached 46% and 88% of the maximum specific activity, respectively. On the other hand, the specific activities for internal nanostructures, H-In and N-In, were 26% and 70% of the maximum possible specific activity at the same diffusion coefficients, respectively. Previous reports recommended the use of porous layers with large thickness and high Rf for sluggish reactions, like alcohol and glucose oxidation in fuel cells [68,69]. Unfortunately, the costs of porous layers have not been considered by most previously reported analyses. However, the evaluation of mass activity (Fig. 4 ) shows clearly that external nanostructures, especially H-EX, are capable of fulfilling the requirements of high Rf and low cost. The comparison of mass activity (Fig. 4) exhibited that external nanostructures in general were in preference to internal nanostructures. Actually, the electrochemical active surfaces area for all proposed nanostructures are equal, but the low specific activity of H-In is only one of the reasons that causes the low mass activity compared to the other nanostructures. Additionally, porosity, which is defined as the ratio between the total volume of pores and total layer volume of nanostructures, also had an impact on the mass activity because it specifies the relative required mass of metal in each nanostructure [56]. The porosity of H-Ex, H-In, N-Ex and N-In was 99.9%, 0.1%, 80.6% and 19.4%, respectively. The values of porosity were complement to each other because nanostructures in this paper were designed in a way that internal nanostructures were the complement of external nanostructures, i.e., the void phase in external nanostructures was the solid phase in the internal structures and vice versa (Figs. 1 and 2). At low diffusion coefficients (D <5×10−9 m2/s), the mass activity of H-Ex is higher than that of N-Ex although H-Ex has higher specific activity and higher porosity (Fig. 4). The reason for that is the roughness factor, which has also an additional impact on the mass activity because of its influence on the total produced current. The roughness factors of hierarchical nanostructures considered in this paper is less than that of non-hierarchical nanostructures. The nanostructures with low Rf were considered in simulations because of the computational limitation. However, high Rf leads to high currents and high mass activity only if the specific activity is high. 3.2 Diffusional resistance and Thiele modulus The investigation results of Thiele modulus (Fig. 5 ) are consistent with the results of the specific activity (Fig. 3). H-Ex nanostructures has apparently the lowest value of Thiele modulus, which means lowest diffusional resistance among other nanostructures (Fig. 5). For each nanostructure, Thiele modulus has the maximum value at D =10−11 m2/s, but only H-Ex nanostructures feature a kinetic controlled regime (ϕn =1) [63]. Apparently, external nanostructures have an enhanced mass transport compared to internal nanostructures. Thiele Modulus for N-Ex nanostructures at D =10−9 m2/s and 10−8 m2/s are 1.6 and 0.5, respectively. Thus, it becomes a kinetic controlled regime within this diffusion range. On the other hand, H-In shows slightly higher values of Thiele modulus compared to N-In. Thus, the macropores in the hierarchical internal nanostructures are significant because of their influence on macropore volume fraction and on the diffusion length Lp (Fig. 2). Optimization of macropores in hierarchical internal nanostructures is well discussed in literature [42–49]. On the contrary, the macrostructure in H-Ex is not part of the diffusion volume and do not increase the diffusion length. However, macropore in H-Ex increases the volume fraction of void-phase at constant catalytic area ( A r / V D factor in Thiele modulus). The high volume fraction and the short diffusion length are the parameters that cause the high pore accessibility and high specific activity of the H-Ex. N-Ex does not have shorter diffusion length compared to N-In, but it has higher volume fraction of void-phase, and therefore higher pore accessibility and specific activity. However, at D =10−8 m2/s, all investigated nanostructures turn into kinetic controlled regimes at which Thiele modulus of hierarchical and non-hierarchical internal nanostructures are about 1. When diffusion coefficient is higher than 10−7 m2/s, Thiele modulus approaches to zero, which means that the pores in all cases do not exert any diffusional resistance on the active species. The effectiveness factor reaches 1 only when the interior surface of pore is exposed to the external surface concentration, i.e., diffusional resistance inside the pore is zero [61]. In contrast, the effectiveness factor value of zero happens only if the molecules are not able to diffuse inside the pore. Therefore, the effectiveness factor demonstrates the efficiency of the catalyst based on the mass transportation inside pores. The simulations were performed for two standard heterogeneous rate constant k 0. For slow kinetics k 0 =0.0324cm/s (Fig. 6 a), H-Ex nanostructures exhibits effectiveness factors more than 0.7 in the whole simulated diffusion coefficients range. Furthermore, for D larger than 10−10 m2/s, the effectiveness factor approaches even to 1 revealing the complete utilization of catalyst. For diffusion coefficients less than 10−9 m2/s, both types of internal nanostructures exhibit effectiveness factors of less than 0.30, while N-Ex nanostructure overstep this value to 0.57. At D =10−8 m2/s, all nanostructures have the effectiveness factor of more than 0.7. Certainly, the effectiveness factors of all nanostructures start converge to 1 for D higher than 10−7 m2/s as a result of the low diffusion resistance inside the pores. These results confirm the conclusion drawn from investigation of specific activity and Thiele modulus that the diffusional resistance at D larger than 10−7 m2/s disappeared in all simulated nanostructures and the results were influenced only by the active surface area and the kinetic parameters. In order to examine the effect of catalytic activity on the effectiveness factor of porous electrode with respect to the wide range of D, we also performed the calculations for extreme value of k 0. Mostly, the high value of k 0 reduces the efficiency of the porous layer at specific D (Fig. 6a and b). Increasing of k 0 by one-order results in shifting of the effectiveness factor curves one order as well towards higher diffusion coefficients (Fig. 6a and b). Thus, low pore accessibility is not only a result of low values of D but also high values of k 0. Consequently, the ratio between the values k 0 and D for any active species or any active surface under any condition defines the catalytic efficiency of porous structures towards active species. Fig. 6c shows the catalytic efficiency of the four investigated nanostructures with respect to k 0/D ratio. Every nanostructure reveals its own efficiency profile, but only the H-Ex nanostructures feature a high catalytic efficiency in a very wide range of k 0/D, which proves the distinguished pore accessibility of this type of nanostructures. It should be noted that the effect of external conditions like temperature, which influence k 0 of catalyst and D of reactants, [53] was not considered by our investigations. Nevertheless, k 0/D ratio defines the catalytic efficiency of any type of nanostructures and can be used as universal parameter for evaluation. If external conditions influence k 0 and D, the k 0/D ratio will deviate from the current position to a new one within the effectiveness factor representation as in Fig. 6c. Therefore, our approach illustrates the pore accessibility and mass transport based on the efficiency of porous layers, which is influenced by D, k 0 and pore morphology independent of external conditions. 3.3 Investigation of pH-shift Surface poisoning effect [22,70,71] and pH-shift in the direct vicinity of the electrode are important issues that are influenced by the mass transportation of reaction products [23,72], like H+ [23], CO2 [21], and CO [71]. In Fig. 7 , pH-value in the direct vicinity of the porous electrode is discussed with respect to diffusion coefficient. The values of pH are almost about 7.4, i.e., no significant shift in pH-value is noticed for the simulated geometrical parameters. However, this paper includes a discussion of pH-shift despite the insignificant pH-shift, because larger pH-shift in reality is more likely than what is observed in simulations. There are several reasons for the expected larger pH-shift or surface poisoning: • the number of electrons released by oxidation process of organic fuels, like methanol [73,74], ethanol [75], formic acid [73] and glucose [76], is higher than 1-electron which increases the number of produced protons; • the roughness factor and catalytic surface area of many porous films are much higher than that used in the simulation, for example, the state of the art Rf is about 6500 [21] and the simulated non-hierarchical nanostructures had Rf of about 32 only; • the thickness of the simulated layer was 200nm which is thinner than the thickness discussed in literature [19,77–80]. With respect to Thiele modulus, the higher the thickness the higher the diffusional resistance. Accordingly, the product molecules, like H+, are trapped in the pores of thicker layers, and consequently increases the acidification in the vicinity of the electrode surface; • the adsorption of redox reaction products, like CO [71], at the surface was not considered in the simulation. As shown in Fig. 7, H-Ex nanostructures exhibit a distinguished mass transport of protons. The very low diffusional resistance, as discussed in Thiele modulus, inside hierarchical external nanostructures is reflected on the diffusion of protons as well. Although H-Ex showed kinetic controlled regime, which means low diffusional resistance inside pores, high active species concentration and high protons production rate, there is no noticeable pH-shift even at high diffusion coefficient. Additionally, N-Ex nanostructures induced pH-shift is less than that of internal nanostructures because of low diffusional resistance. The diffusional resistance can be considered as a key-factor in pH-shift. Therefore, external nanostructures generate always smaller pH-shift than the internal nanostructures. Additionally, the deviation on pH-value in our simulations indicated the diffusional resistance in simulated nanostructures. The diffusional resistance from the lowest to the highest was in the following order: H-Ex, N-Ex, N-In, H-In. 4 Conclusions In this paper, the catalytic efficiencies of four nanostructures, hierarchical external/internal and non-hierarchical external/internal, were analytically investigated by evaluating and comparing the pore accessibility from the perspective of mass transfer rate and catalytic activity inside these nanostructures. Simulations discussed the influence of pore accessibility along with porosity and roughness factor on specific activity and mass activity of nanostructures. External nanostructures, especially hierarchical nanostructures, exhibited very low diffusional resistance inside pores compared to internal nanostructures because of high void-phase volume fraction and shorter diffusion path. This finding was proved by examination of Thiele modulus. Thiele modulus at the given k 0 showed that hierarchical external nanostructures exhibited kinetic controlled regime even at low diffusion coefficients, while internal nanostructures showed kinetic controlled regime only when diffusion coefficient was larger than 10−8 m2/s. The high diffusional resistance inside the internal nanostructures was a drawback for mass transport of educts and products. Therefore, internal nanostructures compared to external nanostructures had lower specific activity, lower mass activity and larger deviation of local pH-value. Accordingly, internal nanostructures suffer from the pH-shift and poisoning effect more than external nanostructures. Thereby, hierarchical external nanostructures are the best candidate for fuel cell applications, alcohol oxidation and other catalytic applications that have sluggish kinetics. The symmetry limitations in hierarchical nanostructures were overcome in this paper by using three-dimensional simulation. The proposed 3D models for catalytic activity investigations represent a universal model that can be employed in further investigations. There are planed further works for investigations of effects of morphology characteristics, macropore-size as well as the influence of laminar flow as an additional source of molecules mass transport. Additionally, temperature and adsorption are further interesting parameters for extended investigations. To our knowledge, it is the first work investigating the pore accessibility by 3D simulation, that consider not only the mass transport based on geometrical parameters but also the catalytic activity inside the pore. coredata.dc:description: The distinct organization of nanostructured materials influences several catalytic characteristics, like selectivity, sensitivity or catalytic efficiency. This paper studies the effect of geometrical configuration of nanostructured catalyst on mass transport and catalytic activity based on 3D simulations of hierarchical external, hierarchical internal, non-hierarchical external and non-hierarchical internal nanostructures. Generally, external nanostructures revealed higher utilization of catalytic surface than the internal nanostructures. Among the four investigated nanostructures, the mass transport in hierarchical external nanostructures was found to be the best; they even showed kinetic controlled regime for the species with low diffusion coefficient. In contrast, hierarchical internal nanostructures showed slightly less specific activity than non-hierarchical internal nanostructures because of higher total diffusional resistance and longer diffusional path. As a result, although hierarchical nanostructures possess large surface area, only the hierarchical external nanostructures provided an outstanding accessibility of active sites. The obtained results provide the tool for understanding the catalytic efficiency in complex nanostructure and phenomena that are technically difficult to measure.
coredata.dc:title: Mass transport and catalytic activity in hierarchical/non-hierarchical and internal/external nanostructures: A novel comparison using 3D simulation
